) is a language spoken in the

(Labourd, Soule and Basse – Navarre). As a language isolate, it is something of a linguistic curiosity, as it has no relatives among any other living languages, in Europe or anywhere else. The language was long suppressed by national governments in France and Spain; but in the 20th century, it reemerged as a living language, partly as a political statement for Basque independence.

Learning Basque is generally not necessary for communication, as essentially all Basque speakers on the Spanish side of the border are able to speak
as well, while those on the French side of the border are also able to speak
. Nevertheless, locals are proud of their language, so learning at least some basic phrases and greetings would help to endear you to the locals.
Basque pronunciation is quite similar to

value: sort of like s in "see," but pronounced with the tongue further back, on the tip of the ridge behind your teeth
before a vowel, like spanish ñ:
(pronounced like baiña), or like ny  in "canyon"
before a vowel, like li in "million" (an "ly" sound):
in between ts in "pets" and ch in "church"—pronounced with your tongue on the tip of the ridge behind your teeth

but these are not very common.
